In order to make it easier to follow the course topics it would be nice to give clearly structured information rather than showing various Youtube videos and presentation slides throughout the lectures. Most of the time it wasn't very clear what the particular lecture was about and how the material shown corresponded to the courses topics and information given was rather old and sometimes even outdated or incorrect due to its age. Another major issue was the language barrier between students and lecturer. Questions from students weren't answered sufficiently and important information about assignments and the course in general was hard to understand or not given.

I really enjoyed the theoretical part of the lecture and the ongoing little assignments throughout the semester and final task helped to follow and revise the discussed topics. The organisation of the practical part however was a bit problematic since there were changing time schedules every week so that there were ongoing conflicts with other lectures also taking place that day. Also it would be nice to find another solution for the organisation of the Lithuanian and International group works taking place simultaneously, since most of the time we were sitting around and waiting for the lecturers to check on our work but they were occupied with the Lithuanian group. Maybe there is an option to do more combined course work of both groups so that both groups could profit from the exchange.

He is a very nice teacher. He made the subject very pleasant and interesting and gave us many opportunities so that we could pass.
She is a very nice teacher, who has made sure that we learned as much as possible about her subject and provided us with all the help we needed to pass.

I am incredibly disappointed with this teacher. It has been a long time since I had a teacher so unconcerned about her students and with so little empathy. In class she explained the homework in one way and then demanded totally different things that she had never mentioned in class. On the other hand, she never responded to my emails and in class she never solved any of my doubts (she told me that if I had attended more I would not have any doubts), so I had no way to communicate with her (which has given me a lot of helplessness and anxiety during the course). On one occasion I asked her if I could send her my work in PDF instead of Word (since my computer is not compatible with that program), and she told me to buy another computer and failed my work (after all the effort I put into it). In addition, she told me that I could not take the final exam and that I had to take the recovery at the end of June, but thanks to many classmates who complained in the end she let us take it. It is depressing to see how you try so hard to pass the course and you don't see any results. It seemed that the teacher wanted us to fail instead of learning and passing. If in the end I passed the course it was because I earned it with my effort, not because she taught me something. Personally, I consider the content of this subject to be one of the most entertaining and enjoyable, but because of the teacher it was the worst by far. I firmly believe that this teacher should rethink the way she teaches.

Lecture's were rather boring, that's why I assume attendance was marked (10% of the final grade).

The professor was very confusing imprecise from the very begininning. Many problems could have been avoided and time saved if the professor was more clear. Even though I am satisfied with my grade, assessment was not transparent at all and kind of mysterious (weird and unclear grading system and no option to get a grade from single tasks by e-mail or Moodle). The teacher was rather unhelpful and changing his mind many times. Very common answer to most of the questions was: "we will see".

Preparing the whole report by handwriting on blank white sheets in digital era is totally incomprehensible for me. It is also time-consuming without a reason. As engineers we will definitely work with computers in the future, whilst there was no possibility to develop simple digital skills as creating graphs which is not that easy. I also know that the report of one of the students was completely rejected only because it was written on checked paper. We were not even allowed to print the cover pages with university's logo.

Nevertheless, the most disappointing part was laboratory classes in a normal classroom. We have not touched any equipment or seen any experiment even once. Generally, during practical and laboratory works we were only preparing the reports which we could easily do at home without losing anything as there was nothing to see or do in person. It was necessary to come to practical and laboratory works only to get initial data, as the teacher did not even explain thoroughly the calculation procedure. Just the example was given. Initial data could not have been obtained in any different way than during the lecture. I tried during consultation or even during classes with Lithuanian groups. There was a possibility to make up for lost classes (meaning only: get initial data later), but only two of them. Fortunately, I could attend the first exam, but imminence of coming straight to a retake was close. I was reallly doing everything to show engagement and that I care. I chose overlapping lectures, which of course was my problem, but I asked the professor a few times at the beginning of the semester if he agreed. I experienced aforementioned troubles because of that. If I had known that, I would have considered choosing a different non-overlapping subject. I missed many more important lectures of another subject because of getting the initial data.

Overall, the subject was extremely disappointing and mundane, but it could easily be one of the most interesting once.

The Moodle course with all necessary materials should have been created at the beginning of the semester. Everything needed to do homework was sent on time, but materials for the exam definitely too late in the second half of May. Moodle course was never created, even though it was promised many times.

Lectures almost always began 10 minutes late.

Homework required a lot of effort, but it was only poor 4% of the final grade, whilst the materials to prepare for the important final exam (70% of the final grade) were sent much too late. Homework was also assessed quite late and there was not much time to correct it so that it was accepted.

The lecturer's english was a problem from the beginning, when it was hard to understand some of the subject criteria, and it was hard to ask for an explanation.  Also he barely answered to emails. If anybody wanted any more information, we had to use the one consultation hour, where a line of usually 20 people formed, so it was just more wasted time.

He did't fully explain the grading system, as defence of the practical/laboratory works was never mentioned until 2 weeks before the end of semester. Then it was never explained how it would affect our grades, and only after the defence (which was a test), and only after us asking, we learned that if it is not graded positevily, we could not attend the exam. Even after the exam, we are not aware of what our grades are from the semester's worth of work.

The method of the practical/laboratory works belong to history. We had to follow a certain "methodology of work", which we had to rewrite on a paper. We could've also used the original printed version but not tablets or computer. Such paper wasting and not practicing using computational programs does not belong into this age. Most of the time spent for this subject was "wasted" time, as it was spent "copying" information or tables.

Overall, just very confusing, and I doubt I will use any of the information in my future career, and vice-versa, the things I will most likely use were not taught proficciently.
NOT CLEAR METHOD OF VALUATION
